reasoning_details.text:
**Revising Crawler Plans**

I'm working on updating the crawler strategy document. My current focus is on incorporating a new folder-based data organization. I am researching the best way to handle featured images and store them in WebP format. Finally, I'm thinking about updating the metadata fields.


**Initiating Analysis Phase**

I've begun by thoroughly examining the existing crawler strategy document to establish a baseline. Following that, I'm diving into the implementation details by reviewing the crawler script. I'm hoping this will provide a clear understanding of the present crawler. My next step will be to explore image handling on n8n.io and a competitor site.

      "description": "This n8n template builds a simple WhatsApp chabot acting as a Sales Agent. The Agent is backed by a product catalog vector store to better answer user's questions.

This template is intended to help introduce n8n users interested in building with WhatsApp.

How it works
This template is in 2 parts: creating the product catalog vector store and building the WhatsApp AI chatbot.
A product brochure is imported via HTTP request node and its text contents extracted.
The text contents are then uploaded to the in-memory vector store to build a knowledgebase for the chatbot.
A WhatsApp trigger is used to capture messages from customers where non-text messages are filtered out.
The customer's message is sent to the AI Agent which queries the product catalogue using the vector store tool.
The Agent's response is sent back to the user via the WhatsApp node.

How to use

Once you've setup and configured your WhatsApp account and credentials
First, populate the vector store by clicking the "Test Workflow" button.
Next, activate the workflow to enable the WhatsApp chatbot.
Message your designated WhatsApp number and you should receive a message from the AI sales agent.
Tweak datasource and behaviour as required.

Requirements
WhatsApp Business Account
OpenAI for LLM

Customising this workflow

Upgrade the vector store to Qdrant for persistance and production use-cases.
Handle different WhatsApp message types for a more rich and engaging experience for customers.",

How It Works  
Trigger: The workflow can be started manually ("When clicking â€˜Test workflowâ€™") or scheduled ("Schedule Trigger") to run at regular intervals (e.g., every 5 minutes).  
Fetch Data: The "Get new video" node retrieves unfilled video requests from a Google Sheet (rows where the "VIDEO" column is empty).  
Video Creation:  
   The "Set data" node formats the prompt and duration from the Google Sheet.  
   The "Create Video" node sends a request to the Fal.run API (Google Veo3) to generate a video based on the prompt.  
Status Check:  
   The "Wait 60 sec." node pauses execution for 60 seconds.  
   The "Get status" node checks the video generation status. If the status is "COMPLETED," the workflow proceeds; otherwise, it waits again.  
Video Processing:  
   The "Get Url Video" node fetches the video URL.  
   The "Generate title" node uses OpenAI (GPT-4.1) to create an SEO-optimized YouTube title.  
   The "Get File Video" node downloads the video file.  
Upload & Update:  
   The "Upload Video" node saves the video to Google Drive.  
   The "HTTP Request" node uploads the video to YouTube via the Upload-Post API.  
   The "Update Youtube URL" and "Update result" nodes update the Google Sheet with the video URL and YouTube link.  

Set Up Steps  
Google Sheet Setup:  
   Create a Google Sheet with columns: PROMPT, DURATION, VIDEO, and YOUTUBE_URL.  
   Share the Sheet link in the "Get new video" node.  

API Keys:  
   Obtain a Fal.run API key (for Veo3) and set it in the "Create Video" node (Header: Authorization: Key YOURAPIKEY).  
   Get an Upload-Post API key (for YouTube uploads) and configure the "HTTP Request" node (Header: Authorization: Apikey YOUR_API_KEY).  

YouTube Upload Configuration:  
   Replace YOUR_USERNAME in the "HTTP Request" node with your Upload-Post profile name.  

Schedule Trigger:  
   Configure the "Schedule Trigger" node to run periodically (e.g., every 5 minutes).  

Need help customizing?

By leveraging n8n core nodes, it scrapes business emails from Google Maps without relying on third-party APIs or paid services, ensuring there are no additional costs involved.

Ideal for small business owners, freelancers, and agencies, this template automates the process of collecting contact information for targeted outreach, making it a powerful tool for anyone looking to scale their lead generation efforts without incurring extra expenses.

You can watch the video tutorial here: https://youtu.be/HaiO-UeiKBA

How it works
This template streamlines email scraping from Google Maps using only n8n core nodes, ensuring a completely free and self-contained solution. Hereâ€™s how it operates:

Input Queries
You provide a list of queries, each consisting of keywords related to the type of business you want to target and the specific region or subregion youâ€™re interested in.

Iterates through Queries
The workflow processes each query one at a time. For each query, it triggers a sub-workflow dedicated to handling the scraping tasks.

Scrapes Google Maps for URLs
Using these queries, the workflow scrapes Google Maps to collect URLs of business listings matching the provided criteria.

Fetches HTML Content
The workflow then fetches the HTML pages of the collected URLs for further processing.

Extracts Emails

Using a Code Node with custom JavaScript, the workflow runs regular expressions on the HTML content to extract business email addresses.

Setup

Configure the Google Sheets Node:

Run the workflow:
Click on "Test workflow" and watch your Google Sheets document gradually receive business email addresses.

**Investigating API Endpoint**

I've hit a roadblock with the API endpoint, initially getting a 404 error. I'm exploring alternative possibilities for the URL. I will use the information from the `n8n-mcp` tool instead, as that seems to have the template access I need. A simpler approach might be `mcp_n8n-mcp_get`.


**Finding Image Strategy**

My focus has shifted toward finding a robust image strategy. I've abandoned direct URL hunting and am now leaning toward using a headless browser to capture a screenshot of the workflow preview. Converting this to WebP seems like the best approach given the dynamic nature of these images. The user's input regarding WebP and the challenges of dynamic images from n8n.io reinforces this direction. I'm exploring the `browser_action` to navigate the page and capture the crucial preview area.


**Refining Image Retrieval**

My focus has sharpened on image retrieval. I've abandoned the console log and network request inspection attempts after realizing their limitations. Now, I'm fully committed to a multi-pronged approach, based on the `n8n-mcp` tool. First I'll get direct CDN links if they exist, and then I will use a headless browser to capture a screenshot and use `sharp` to convert to WebP. The folder-based data structure and `public/data/workflows/` storage are being kept.


**Constructing Workflow Overview**

I'm now fully immersed in developing a more comprehensive plan. I need to integrate the image retrieval process with the workflow saving mechanism. I aim to create a function that handles both image extraction (using my previous techniques) and updates the workflow data structure, ensuring both the image and the associated workflow are saved correctly. The image handling needs to be robust, as it's key to the user experience.

**Defining the Workflow Source**

I'm currently working to determine how n8n.io generates and provides its workflow preview images. My observations suggest they are dynamically generated SVGs or served via specific CDN links, and I'll keep digging. For example, I need to figure out how they get the details of the n8n.io workflow.


**Refining the Image Acquisition**

I've pinpointed that the `<n8n-demo>` component contains the preview images. I'm focusing on two acquisition strategies: checking for a CDN-like endpoint such as `https://n8n.io/api/v1/templates/[ID]/screenshot` (Option A), and using a headless browser (Playwright/Puppeteer) to capture the preview area (Option B). I'm leaning toward Option B as the most reliable approach. Also, I'm defining a folder structure to house workflow data and images, in order to enable direct URL image access. Finally, I've decided to convert the images to WebP format, using `sharp` library, for optimized image delivery.


**Incorporating Image References**

I'm now incorporating a `featuredImage` field within `metadata.json` to store image paths relative to the `public/` directory. This is a recent development. I've also commenced modifying `plans/CONTENT_CRAWLER_STRATEGY.md` to reflect these changes in detail.
